prompt: Facts: Incident occurred on October 13, 1979, in Village Khabra Kalan, District Hissar, Haryana.; Dispute arose over the ownership and cultivation of a piece of land between the complainant party (Prabhu Dayal's group) and the accused party (Prem Chand's group).; On the day of the incident, the complainant party was allegedly ploughing the disputed land.; The accused party, numbering around 12-13 persons including Prem Chand, arrived armed with lathis, gandasis (sharp-edged weapons), and possibly other weapons.; An altercation ensued, during which the accused party allegedly attacked Prabhu Dayal and other members of his group (including Ram Kumar, Om Prakash, Manphool).; Prabhu Dayal sustained multiple injuries, including head injuries, allegedly inflicted by the accused.; Other members of the complainant party also sustained injuries.; Prabhu Dayal succumbed to his injuries later.; FIR was lodged, investigation conducted, and chargesheet filed against the accused.; Medical evidence (post-mortem report of Prabhu Dayal, injury reports of others) documented the injuries sustained.; Eyewitness accounts were provided primarily by the injured persons and other members of the complainant party.; Trial Court convicted the accused under Sections 148, 302/149, 325/149, 324/149, and 323/149 IPC.; On appeal, the High Court of Punjab & Haryana acquitted all the accused, primarily accepting the plea of private defence and finding inconsistencies in prosecution evidence.; The State of Haryana filed an appeal before the Supreme Court against the High Court's acquittal judgment. | IPC: Section 147 (Rioting), Section 148 (Rioting, armed with deadly weapon), Section 149 (Every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object), Section 302 (Punishment for murder), Section 304 Part I (Culpable homicide not amounting to murder - causing death with intention/knowledge), Section 323 (Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt), Section 324 (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means), Section 325 (Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt), Section 96 (Things done in private defence), Section 97 (Right of private defence of the body and of property), Section 100 (When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death), Section 103 (When the right of private defence of property extends to causing death)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The High Court erred in reversing the Trial Court's conviction; the evidence conclusively proved the accused formed an unlawful assembly with the common object to attack and cause death/grievous hurt.", "precedents": ["Masalti v. State of U.P., AIR 1965 SC 202 (Principles for appreciating evidence in cases involving multiple accused and witnesses; minor discrepancies don't discredit testimony)", "Muniappan v. State of Tamil Nadu, AIR 1981 SC 1220 (Common object need not be proved by direct evidence, can be inferred from circumstances, weapons used, and nature of injuries)", "Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka, (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Scope of interference by appellate court in an appeal against acquittal; reversal justified if trial court view perverse or High Court ignored compelling evidence)"]}, {"argument": "The plea of private defence accepted by the High Court is untenable; the accused were aggressors who came armed to the disputed land being cultivated by the complainants.", "precedents": ["Darshan Singh v. State of Punjab, (2010) 2 SCC 333 (Right of private defence is not available to aggressors; must be danger to life or property)", "Gottipulla Venkatasiva Subbrayanam v. State of Andhra Pradesh, AIR 1970 SC 1079 (Right of private defence against trespass requires specific conditions; cannot justify disproportionate force)", "State of U.P. v. Ram Swarup, AIR 1974 SC 1570 (No right of private defence when accused party goes armed to assert disputed property rights through force)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The High Court rightly acquitted as the prosecution failed to prove the case beyond reasonable doubt; accused acted in legitimate private defence of person and property.", "precedents": ["Darshan Singh v. State of Punjab, (2010) 2 SCC 333 (Principles governing the right of private defence).", "James Martin v. State of Kerala, (2004) 2 SCC 203 (Right extends to causing death under S.100/S.103 IPC if reasonable apprehension exists).", "Yogendra Morarji v. State of Gujarat, AIR 1980 SC 660 (Burden of proof for private defence is preponderance of probabilities, not beyond reasonable doubt)."]}, {"argument": "Significant contradictions and improvements in eyewitness testimonies, coupled with partisan nature of witnesses (being from complainant group), render the prosecution case unreliable.", "precedents": ["Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras, AIR 1957 SC 614 (Classification of witnesses - wholly reliable, wholly unreliable, neither wholly reliable nor wholly unreliable).", "State of U.P. v. Jagdeo, AIR 2003 SC 660 (Testimony of interested witnesses needs careful scrutiny and corroboration if possible).", "Suraj Mal v. State (Delhi Administration), AIR 1979 SC 1408 (Material contradictions regarding genesis of incident or participation can lead to acquittal)."]}, {"argument": "The High Court's finding of acquittal should not be interfered with lightly by the Supreme Court unless the findings are perverse or based on manifest errors of law.", "precedents": ["Sheo Swarup v. King Emperor, AIR 1934 PC 227 (Principles guiding appellate courts in appeals against acquittal - presumption of innocence reinforced).", "Balak Ram v. State of U.P., AIR 1974 SC 2165 (Appellate court should be slow to interfere with acquittal if the view taken by trial/lower appellate court is reasonable).", "Arunachalam v. Sadhanantham, AIR 1979 SC 1284 (Reversal of acquittal only if conclusions are 'manifestly erroneous' or 'palpably wrong')."]}, {"argument": "Even if an offence occurred, the common object was not murder (S. 302/149); at most, it could be culpable homicide or causing grievous hurt, attributable only to specific individuals.", "precedents": ["Roy Fernandes v. State of Goa, (2012) 3 SCC 221 (Distinction between common object and common intention; common object must be clearly established).", "Bhagwan Singh v. State of M.P., (2002) 4 SCC 85 (If common object was limited, members not liable for graver offence committed individually unless it was known to be likely).", "Willie (William) Slaney v. State of M.P., AIR 1956 SC 116 (Importance of framing correct charges, distinction between S.34 and S.149)."]}]}
